# Carbazole/Sulfone Hybrid D π.\\pmb { \\pi } ^ { . }π. -A-Structured Bipolar Fluorophores for High-Efficiency Blue-Violet Electroluminescence

Ju haChenanKeug unCa ZhenXu ui Zha Yi Yuan,and Chun-Sing Le

Nogaoecrboto nd y Lboaoy oemal ve OptrMa,  
Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, P.R. China

Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR, P.R. China  
§Department of Chemistry, Shantou University, Guangdong 515063, P.R. China

⊗\\otimes⊗ Supporting Information

ABSTRACT: Based on a D-π-A structural strategy incorporating carbazole as a mild electron-donor and sulfone as an electron-acceptor with a π\\piπ conjugation-breaking feature, two novel blue-violet emitting materials ( CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and \\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2 $ were successfully designed and synthesized. The two compounds exhibit high-efficiency fluorescent emissions of intramolecular charge-transfer transition type, with impressively high quantum yields in both solution and flm states. CIE, below 0.06 and excellent current/ power efficiencies up to 1.89 cd $\\mathrm { A ^ { - 1 } / 1 . 5 8 ~ \\ l m ^ { ' } ~ W ^ { - 1 } } were achieved with their corresponding nondoped devices. These performances currently represent the best results for OLEDs with CIEy < 0.06.\\mathrm { C I E } \_ { y } \\ < \\ 0 . 0 6 .CIEy​ < 0.06. different electroluminescence performance of the two fluorophores.

![](https://storage.treer.ai/images/eb902273358909f04f007bf7ad7d5563776385bbd1a75d84e721edcc4d6a7b9e.jpg)

KEYwORDS: blue-violet electroluminescence, carbazole, sulfone, bipolar fluorophor

# INTRODUCTION

Blue-violet/violet light-emitting materials are of great significance for their unique applications in flat-panel displays1 and high-density information storage.2 Especially in full-color displays, the short-wavelength emission can not only serve as an excitation source for emission over the whole visible range and white light emission, but also is a key component for effectively reducing the power consumption of the display.3 Therefore, the development of high-efficiency blue-violet to violet emitting materials and devices are important for the rapidly developing organic light-emitting device (OLED) technology.

However, so far, the reports of efficient OLEDs with their color coordinates in the Commission Internationale de L'Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity diagram beyond the standard blue (CIE coordinates of 0.15, 0.06), are still rare.4 Many efficient emitters, such as anthracene,5 fluorene,6 styrylarylene7 and pyrene derivatives,8 and so forth, are based on molecular structures of large π\\piπ conjugation which can give highly emissive π−π∗\\pi - \\pi ^ { \* }π−π∗ transition states upon excitation. However, for realizing blue-violet or violet emission the π\\piπ conjugation of organic molecules must be strictly confined. This will then either cause co-instantaneous decrease of fluorescent quantum yield and charge-transporting ability, or to some extent increase the synthetic difficulty when large molecular weight and/or bulky structure are usually required for good thermal and morphological stability. Very recently, donor- π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ acceptor (D-π- A) type fluorophores have attracted much attention because they not only show high fluorescent quantum yields owing to the effective radiative decay of their excited intramolecular charge-transfer (ICT) state but also possess impressive bipolar charge-transporting properties for their constituting hole- and electron-transporting moieties.1° As a result, the use of D--A type fluorophores can effectively simplify the device configrations 10a,f,e,g^ { 1 0 \\mathrm { a } , \\mathbf { f } , \\mathrm { e } , \\mathrm { g } }10a,f,e,g cence (EL) efficiencies of OLEDs.1 However, except for the enlarged π\\piπ conjugation, the ICT trend in such molecules indeed could also lead to remarkable fluorescence red shifts.10c

Basing on a central A group of phosphine oxide that can break the local π\\piπ conjugation, Liu et al. recently developed a series of efficient deep-blue emitters which show electroluminescence CIE coordinates around (0.15, 0.10).10 Whereas room for further blue-shifting the emission still remains because the strong electron-donating NNN phenylnaphthalen-1-aminegroup (with relatively low oxidation potentials)10 and long π\\piπ bridges between the D and A units (3 to 4 benzene rings) were used in these emitters. Once replaced by other less electron-rich donors and shorter π\\piπ bridges, respectively, to limit the ICT trend and the molecular conjugation, the light emission can be further adjusted to shorter wavelength. Moss et al. systematically studied the photophysics of a series of electron-accepting dibenzothiophene S,S-dioxide (DBTO)-based fluorophores whic are modified with different kinds of D units.1 Among them, the carbazole/DBTO-connected fluorophores exhibit blue to violet (450 to 408 nm4 0 8 ~ \\mathrm { n m }408 nm )fluorescence in toluene solution. Their fluorescent quantum yields are yet either moderate (0.58) or even low (0.25). It is also noticeable that substantial conjugation exists across the DBTO unit, still leaving the chance for further blue-shifting the emission. Thereby, the key point for designing high-efficiency blue-violet to violet electroluminescence materials is to suitably control the π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ conjugation enlargement and the ICT trend inside the molecules.

![](https://storage.treer.ai/images/7bdbc5d01b43ddd08cac674f0c63e55d3b3bc72266094c1bd20a9caf92b17627.jpg)  
Scheme 1. Synthesis of Czs1\\mathbf { C } \\mathbf { z } \\mathbf { s } \\mathbf { 1 }Czs1 and CzS2

Herein, we utilized a carbazole/sulfone hybrid design strategy to obtain two novel efficient blue-violet fluorophores, di(4-(4-(carbazol-9-yl)phenyl)phenyl)sulfone (CzS1)\\mathbf { ( C z S 1 ) }(CzS1) and di(4- (9-phenylcarbazol-3-yl)phenyl)sulfone (CzS2)\\mathbf { ( C z S 2 ) }(CzS2) (Scheme 1). The widely used hole-transporting moiety, carbazole, was selected as the electron-donor (D) for its relatively mild electron-donating ability as compared to other arylamines.10c These D--A type molecules could thus have relatively weak ICT trends, which is beneficial for generating short-wavelength emissions. Besides, the sulfone group was chosen as the electron-acceptor (A) for its excellent electron injection/ as linked to two freely rotatable benzene rings in this work, can also serve as a π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ conjugation breaker because of its tetrahedral electronic conformation which could effectively confine the π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ . conjugation of the molecules. Finally, these compounds were designed to be bulky to enhance their morphological and thermal stability by using a symmetrical D. π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ A π\\piπ D structure. Bipolar charge-transporting characteristics of CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 were demonstrated with single-carrier type devices. Nondoped OLEDs based on the two novel fluorophores show blue-violet light emissions with CIEx,y\\mathrm { C I E } \_ { \\mathrm { x , y } }CIEx,y​ of (0.157, 0.055) and (0.157, 0.044), respectively. The CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 -based device exhibited excellent EL performance with high external quantum efficiency (EQE) of 4.2%4 . 2 \\%4.2% ,current efficiency (CE) of 1.89 cd A−1\\mathbf { A } ^ { - 1 }A−1 ,and power efficiency (PE) of 1.58lmW−11 . 5 8 \\mathrm { l m } \\mathrm { W } ^ { - 1 }1.58lmW−1 Performances of the devices are among the best of OLEDs with CIEy\\mathrm { C I E } \_ { y }CIEy​ below 0.06. In particular, to the best of our knowledge, the CE and PE obtained here have reached the highest values of reported blue-violet/violet OLEDs with CIEy\\mathrm { C I E } \_ { y }CIEy​ below 0.06.

# EXPERIMENTAL SECTION

General Procedures. 1H^ 1 \\mathrm { H }1H and 13C^ { 1 3 } \\mathrm { C }13C NMR spectra were measured with a Varian Gemini-400 Varian spectrometer. Mass spectra were recorded on a Finnigan 4021C GC-MS spectrometer. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was performed using a Perkin-Elmer Pyris DSC 6 instrument operated at a heating rate of 10 ∘C min−11 0 \\ ^ { \\circ } \\mathrm { C } \\ \\mathrm { m i n ^ { - 1 } }10 ∘C min−1 in a nitrogen atmosphere. The glass transition temperature (Tg)( T \_ { \\mathrm { g } } )(Tg​) was determined from the second heating scan. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was undertaken using a TA SDT Q600 instrument. The thermal stability of the samples under a nitrogen atmosphere was determined by measuring their weight losses while heating at a rate of 20∘C min−12 0 \\mathrm { ^ { \\circ } C \\ m i n ^ { - 1 } }20∘C min−1 .The absorption and emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi U-3010 UV-vis spectrophotometer and a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer, respectively. The film photoluminescence quantum yield was measured by the integrating sphere method, and the emission decay profile was measured with an Edinburgh F900 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Cyclic voltammetry was performed with a CHI600A analyzer with the scan rate of 100 mV s−11 0 0 \\ \\mathrm { m V \\ s ^ { - 1 } }100 mV s−1 at room temperature. The electrolytic cell was a conventional three-electrode cell in which a glassy carbon working electrode, a Pt wise auxiliary electrode, and an aqueous saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference electrode were employed. The ferrocene/ ferrocenium couple was used as the internal standard.

Quantum Calculation. Theoretical calculation of the compounds was carried out using the Gaussian-03 program. Density functional theory (DFT) B3LPY/6-31G(d) was used to determine and optimize the structures. Optimized structures were used for the calculation. No negative mode was found, indicating that the systems indeed correspond to a local energy minimum.

OLED Fabrication and Measurement. ITO coated glass with a sheet resistance of 30 Ω3 0 ~ \\Omega30 Ω square−1 was used as the substrate. Before device fabrication, the ITO glass substrates were cleaned with isopropyl alcohol and deionized water, dried in an oven at 120 ∘C,1 2 0 \\ ^ { \\circ } \\mathrm { C } ,120 ∘C, treated with UV-ozone, and finally transferred to a vacuum deposition system with a base pressure better than 1×10−61 \\times 1 0 ^ { - 6 }1×10−6 Torr for organic and metal deposition. The devices were fabricated by evaporating organic layers with an evaporation rate of 1−2 A ^s−11 - 2 \\hat { \\mathrm { ~ A ~ } } s ^ { - 1 }1−2 A ^s−1 The cathode was completed through thermal deposition of LiF at a deposition rate of 0.1 A˚ˉ s−10 . 1 \\ \\bar { \\mathrm { \\AA } } \\ s ^ { - 1 }0.1 A˚ˉ s−1 , and then capped with Al metal through thermal evaporation at a rate of 10 A˚s −11 0 \\textrm { \\AA s } ^ { - 1 }10 A˚s −1 The overlap between ITO and Al electrodes was 3.3×3.3 mm23 . 3 \\times 3 . 3 ~ \\mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }3.3×3.3 mm2 as the active emissive area of devices. EL luminescence, spectra, and CIE color coordinates were measured with a Spectrascan PR650 photometer, and the current—voltage characteristics were measured with a computer-controlled Keithley 2400 SourceMeter under ambient atmosphere.

# RESULTS AND DISCUSSION

Synthesis. CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathbf { C } \\mathbf { z } \\mathbf { S } 2CzS2 were similarly prepared through three synthetic steps (Scheme 1) of good yields. Diphenylsulfide was first subjected to the substitution of Br2\\mathrm { B r } \_ { 2 }Br2​ 13 The Br2\\mathrm { B r } \_ { 2 }Br2​ could be rapidly reproduced by H2O2\\mathrm { H } \_ { 2 } \\mathrm { O } \_ { 2 }H2​O2​ in the two-phase system of CH2Cl2/H2O\\mathrm { C H } \_ { 2 } \\mathrm { C l } \_ { 2 } / \\mathrm { H } \_ { 2 } \\mathrm { O }CH2​Cl2​/H2​O which significantly promotes the reaction. The resulting di(4-bromophenyl)sulfide subsequently went through a MnSO4\\mathrm { { \\bf M n S O } \_ { 4 } }MnSO4​ assisted oxidization by KMnO4,14\\mathrm { K M n O \_ { 4 } } , ^ { 1 4 }KMnO4​,14 giving the next intermediate di(4-bromophenyl)sulfone. Finally, palladium(0)-catalyzed Suzuki cross-coupling reaction between 4-(carbazol-9-yl)phenylboronic acid/(9-phenylcarbazol-3-yl)- boronic acid and di(4-bromophenyl)sulfone resulted in the target compounds, CzS1/CzS2\\mathrm { C z S 1 } / \\mathrm { C z S 2 }CzS1/CzS2 . These new compounds were characterized with mass spectrometry, 1H^ 1 \\mathrm { H }1H NMR, 13C^ { 1 3 } \\mathrm { C }13C NMR spectroscopy, and elemental analysis.

Thermal Properties. Their good thermal stability was demonstrated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), showing high decomposition temperatures TdT \_ { \\mathrm { d } }Td​ (corresponding to 5%5 \\%5% weight loss) of 498 ∘C4 9 8 ~ ^ { \\circ } \\mathrm { C }498 ∘C  ′CzS1)\\mathrm { \\ ' C z S 1 } ) ′CzS1) and 486∘C4 8 6 ^ { \\circ } \\mathrm { C }486∘C (CzS2)( \\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2 )(CzS2) , respectively (Figure 1). High glass transition temperatures ∇(Tg){ \\bf \\nabla } ( T \_ { \\mathrm { g } } )∇(Tg​) above 140 ∘C^ \\circ \\mathrm { C }∘C were also obtained via differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) (Figure 1). Such high TgsT \_ { \\mathrm { g } } \\mathrm { s }Tg​s should be attributed to those bulky D π\\piπ A π\\piπ D structures and would benefit the stability of film morphology.

![](https://storage.treer.ai/images/92af11972c47ec9d145e0cd20af7c0b1c7a6f69bdf1218df65435bf93f02aa81.jpg)  
Figure 1. TGA curves (inset: DSC curves) of CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 (a) and CzS2{ \\bf C } { \\bf z } { \\bf S } 2CzS2 (b).

Optical Properties. Photophysical properties of CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathbf { C } \\mathbf { z } \\mathbf { S } 2CzS2 were analyzed using ultraviolet—visible (UV-vis) and photoluminescence (PL) spectrometers. The data are shown in Figure 2, 3 and Table 1. In the absorption spectra of 30 nm3 0 ~ \\mathrm { { n m } }30 nm thick films, the two compounds show similar absorptions where the bands around 345 and 300  nm3 0 0 ~ \\mathrm { ~ n m }300  nm can be respectively attributed to the ICT transition and the carbazole-centered n−π∗\\mathrm { n } \\mathrm { - } \\pi ^ { \\ast }n−π∗ transition. These absorption bands slightly blue-shift in toluene solution while another distinct shoulder band at 332 nm was found for CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 . This may arise from the π−π∗\\pi - \\pi ^ { \* }π−π∗ transition in the donor units. From the film onset absorptions, both of the band gaps (Eg)( E \_ { \\mathrm { g } } )(Eg​) of CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathbf { C } \\mathbf { z } \\mathbf { S } 2CzS2 are determined to be 3.16 eV.3 . 1 6 ~ \\mathrm { e V } .3.16 eV. In the film PL spectra, CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 exhibits a narrow emission around 428 nm4 2 8 ~ \\mathrm { n m }428 nm with a fwhm (full width at halfmaximum) of 56nm,5 6 \\mathrm { n m } ,56nm, while CzS2\\mathbf { C } \\mathbf { z } \\mathbf { S } 2CzS2 shows a relatively blue-shifted emission at 416 nm4 1 6 ~ \\mathrm { n m }416 nm with a fwhm of 51 nm5 1 ~ \\mathrm { { n m } }51 nm Therefore, the film fluorescent emissions of both compounds are located in the short-wavelength spectral region of the whole visible light spectrum. To illustrate the reasonable molecular design in this work, we may also compare their solution PL characteristics with compound 11, namely, 2,8-di( N⋅N \\cdotN⋅ (2-ethylhexyl)-carbazol3-yl) dibenzothiophene-S,S-dioxide, which has the highestenergy fluorescence of 408 nm4 0 8 ~ \\mathrm { n m }408 nm in toluene among its carbazole/ DBTO analogues reported by Moss et al.11 In our case, both of the new compounds give violet fluorescence with maximum wavelengths below 400 nm4 0 0 \\ \\mathrm { n m }400 nm in the same solution. The higher energy fluorescence of our compounds should be primarily ascribed to the reasonable molecular design using conjugationlimited diphenylsulfone block instead of the planar DBTO unit. The ICT characteristics of the two emitters are shown via their gradually red-shifted and broadened fluorescent emissions upon increasing the polarity of solvent (Figure 3). Large increase of the dipole moment from the ground state to the excited state was also calculated from the Lippert—Mataga calculation, 37 D for CzS1\\mathbf { C z S 1 }CzS1 and 24 D2 4 ~ \\mathrm { D }24 D for CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 (see Supporting Information), 15 further reflecting the typical photoinduced ICT process and the effective electronic communication between the donor and acceptor units. In addition, fluorescent quantum yields of CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathbf { C } \\mathbf { z } \\mathbf { S } 2CzS2 were estimated to be approaching unity in toluene, as referenced to quinine sulfate Φf\=0.56\\Phi \_ { \\mathrm { f } } = 0 . 5 6Φf​\=0.56 in 1NH2SO4,\\mathrm { 1 N H \_ { 2 } S O \_ { 4 } } ,1NH2​SO4​, .16 Such high quantum yields (four times over that of compound 11, 0.25) are owing to the suitably modified D. π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ Amolecular structures which could provide highly emissive ICT excited states upon excitation. Even in neat films, these yields still remain impressively high as measured by the integrating sphere method under air condition, 0.98 for CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and 0.79 for CzS2, suggesting that the fluorescence quenching routes in the film have been effectively suppressed, probably owing to the bulky D. π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ A π\\piπ D structures.

Adachi and co-workers have recently made a milestone advance in the organic electroluminescence research field by introducing purely organic molecules that can give efficient thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) through upconversion of triplet to singlet states, and therefore lead to potentially 100%100 \\%100% internal singlet yields.10h,1 Among their reported TADF materials, compound 3, namely, di(4-(3,6-ditert-butylcarbazol-9-yl)phenyl)sulfone, shows pure-blue electroxel Q 9.9%9 . 9 \\%9.9% 1h o onsidering that the two compounds in this work have similar molecular structures with compound 3, we also explore their potential of TADF emission. Supporting Information, Figure S2 shows their room-temperature transient PL decay characteristics in an oxygen-free toluene solution. The samples were freshly nitrogen-purged to avoid any possible triplet quenching by oxygen. It is interesting to find that, in contrast to the case of compound 3 in the report of Adachi et al., both of our new compounds clearly exhibit first-order exponential decays which completely end within a short time range of 20 ns2 0 ~ \\mathrm { n s }20 ns Indeed, no delayed components were observed in both cases, indicating the absence of DATF emission from CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathbf { C } \\mathbf { z } \\mathbf { S } 2CzS2 We may mainly attribute this to the overwhelming emission transition rate over the nonemission transition rate of their photoinduced excited states. As mentioned above, CzS1 and CzS2 achieved near-unity fluorescent quantum yields even in the airequilibrated toluene solution, and therefore one can deduce that the intersystem crossing (ISC) process, one non-emission

On the other hand, as delayed fluorescence is established by the premise of converting the triplet back to a singlet state, the energy distance (ΔEsT)( \\Delta E \_ { \\mathrm { { s T } } } )(ΔEsT​) between the lowest singlet state and the lowest triplet state should be taken into account; generally, the smaller ΔEST\\Delta E \_ { \\mathrm { S T } }ΔEST​ the more efficient the upconversion. Estimated from the low-temperature fluorescence and phosphorescence maxima, we obtained the ΔEST\\Delta E \_ { \\mathrm { S T } }ΔEST​ of 0.62 and 0.65 eV0 . 6 5 \\ \\mathrm { e V }0.65 eV respectively for CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 (see Supporting Information, Figure S3). As a result, these compounds show much larger ΔEST\\Delta E \_ { \\mathrm { S T } }ΔEST​ than the reported 0.32 eV0 . 3 2 ~ \\mathrm { e V }0.32 eV for compound 3, which should dramatically raise the difficulty of up-converting triplet to singlet state to give delayed fluorescence.

Electrochemical Properties. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was conducted to measure the HOMO levels of CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 .From the onset of the oxidation curves (Figure 4), the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) levels were estimated to be −5.61\- 5 . 6 1−5.61 and −5.62  eV\- 5 . 6 2 \\mathrm { ~ \\ e V }−5.62  eV for CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 respectively, by comparing with ferrocene (Fc) Γ(HOMO \=\\mathrm { \\Gamma ( H O M O \\ = }Γ(HOMO \= −(Eˉox+4.8) eVˉ,\- ( \\mathrm { \\bar { \\it E } \_ { o x } } + 4 . 8 ) ~ \\mathrm { e \\bar { V } } ,−(Eˉox​+4.8) eVˉ, .18 Their LUMO levels were further estimated by summing the HOMO levels and the band gaps determined from their absorption edges. These orbital energy levels are listed in Table 1. The similarity of molecular orbital energy levels should be associated with the fact that these molecules incorporate identical functional groups and similar D--A structures. To gain insight into the electronic structures of these compounds, a density functional theory (DFT) calculation was performed at the B3LYP/6-31G (d) level. Figure 5 reveals an obvious separation of the HOMO and the LUMO which are dominantly located on the carbazole and the diphenylsulfone units respectively. This separation should effectively maintain the individual electronic properties of these functional groups an ben anport boh ho n lecons.In addition, it can also be observed that there are still enough HOMO-LUMO overlaps. These are required to guarantee effective electronic communication between the donor and the acceptor, and thus highly emissive ICT excited states which have already been demonstrated by the high fluorescent quantum yields. 20

As shown in Figure 9, all the four single-carrier devices show significant currents, indicating the bipolar charge-transporting abilities of both CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathbf { C } \\mathbf { z } \\mathbf { S } 2CzS2 . Additionally, it is also found that the hole and electron currents of the CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 devices are both much higher, however, less balanced as compared to those of the CzS1 devices. # CONCLUSIONS

In summary, two highly efficient blue-violet fluorophores, CzS1 and CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 , have been developed via a D π\\piπ A structure design strategy which incorporates carbazole as a mild electron-donor and sulfone as an electron-acceptor with a π\\piπ conjugationbreaking feature. Nondoped devices based on the two compounds exhibit blue-violet light emissions with CIE coordinates of (0.157, 0.055) for CzS1\\mathbf { C z S 1 }CzS1 and (0.157, 0.044) for CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 at 100 cd m−21 0 0 \\ c \\mathrm { d } \\ \\mathrm { m } ^ { - 2 }100 cd m−2 respectively. CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 possesses much better balanced bipolar charge-transporting ability, and its electroluminescence device shows high performance with EQE, CE, and PE of 4.2%4 . 2 \\%4.2% ,1.89 cd A−1\\mathbf { A } ^ { - 1 }A−1 ,and 1.58 lm W−1.1 . 5 8 \\ \\mathrm { l m \\ W ^ { - 1 } } .1.58 lm W−1. respectively, which are among the best of blue-violet/violet OLEDs up until now. We here successfully provide an efficient design strategy for high-efficiency short-wavelength fluorophores.

# Carbazole/Sulfone Hybrid D π.\\pmb { \\pi } ^ { . }π. -A-Structured Bipolar Fluorophores for High-Efficiency Blue-Violet Electroluminescence

Ju haChenanKeug unCa ZhenXu ui Zha Yi Yuan,and Chun-Sing Le

Nogaoecrboto nd y Lboaoy oemal ve OptrMa,  
Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, P.R. China

Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR, P.R. China  
§Department of Chemistry, Shantou University, Guangdong 515063, P.R. China

⊗\\otimes⊗ Supporting Information

ABSTRACT: Based on a D-π-A structural strategy incorporating carbazole as a mild electron-donor and sulfone as an electron-acceptor with a π\\piπ conjugation-breaking feature, two novel blue-violet emitting materials ( CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and \\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2 $ were successfully designed and synthesized. The two compounds exhibit high-efficiency fluorescent emissions of intramolecular charge-transfer transition type, with impressively high quantum yields in both solution and flm states. CIE, below 0.06 and excellent current/ power efficiencies up to 1.89 cd $\\mathrm { A ^ { - 1 } / 1 . 5 8 ~ \\ l m ^ { ' } ~ W ^ { - 1 } } were achieved with their corresponding nondoped devices. These performances currently represent the best results for OLEDs with CIEy < 0.06.\\mathrm { C I E } \_ { y } \\ < \\ 0 . 0 6 .CIEy​ < 0.06. different electroluminescence performance of the two fluorophores.

![](https://storage.treer.ai/images/eb902273358909f04f007bf7ad7d5563776385bbd1a75d84e721edcc4d6a7b9e.jpg)

KEYwORDS: blue-violet electroluminescence, carbazole, sulfone, bipolar fluorophor

# INTRODUCTION

Blue-violet/violet light-emitting materials are of great significance for their unique applications in flat-panel displays1 and high-density information storage.2 Especially in full-color displays, the short-wavelength emission can not only serve as an excitation source for emission over the whole visible range and white light emission, but also is a key component for effectively reducing the power consumption of the display.3 Therefore, the development of high-efficiency blue-violet to violet emitting materials and devices are important for the rapidly developing organic light-emitting device (OLED) technology.

However, so far, the reports of efficient OLEDs with their color coordinates in the Commission Internationale de L'Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity diagram beyond the standard blue (CIE coordinates of 0.15, 0.06), are still rare.4 Many efficient emitters, such as anthracene,5 fluorene,6 styrylarylene7 and pyrene derivatives,8 and so forth, are based on molecular structures of large π\\piπ conjugation which can give highly emissive π−π∗\\pi - \\pi ^ { \* }π−π∗ transition states upon excitation. However, for realizing blue-violet or violet emission the π\\piπ conjugation of organic molecules must be strictly confined. This will then either cause co-instantaneous decrease of fluorescent quantum yield and charge-transporting ability, or to some extent increase the synthetic difficulty when large molecular weight and/or bulky structure are usually required for good thermal and morphological stability. Very recently, donor- π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ acceptor (D-π- A) type fluorophores have attracted much attention because they not only show high fluorescent quantum yields owing to the effective radiative decay of their excited intramolecular charge-transfer (ICT) state but also possess impressive bipolar charge-transporting properties for their constituting hole- and electron-transporting moieties.1° As a result, the use of D--A type fluorophores can effectively simplify the device configrations 10a,f,e,g^ { 1 0 \\mathrm { a } , \\mathbf { f } , \\mathrm { e } , \\mathrm { g } }10a,f,e,g cence (EL) efficiencies of OLEDs.1 However, except for the enlarged π\\piπ conjugation, the ICT trend in such molecules indeed could also lead to remarkable fluorescence red shifts.10c

Basing on a central A group of phosphine oxide that can break the local π\\piπ conjugation, Liu et al. recently developed a series of efficient deep-blue emitters which show electroluminescence CIE coordinates around (0.15, 0.10).10 Whereas room for further blue-shifting the emission still remains because the strong electron-donating NNN phenylnaphthalen-1-aminegroup (with relatively low oxidation potentials)10 and long π\\piπ bridges between the D and A units (3 to 4 benzene rings) were used in these emitters. Once replaced by other less electron-rich donors and shorter π\\piπ bridges, respectively, to limit the ICT trend and the molecular conjugation, the light emission can be further adjusted to shorter wavelength. Moss et al. systematically studied the photophysics of a series of electron-accepting dibenzothiophene S,S-dioxide (DBTO)-based fluorophores whic are modified with different kinds of D units.1 Among them, the carbazole/DBTO-connected fluorophores exhibit blue to violet (450 to 408 nm4 0 8 ~ \\mathrm { n m }408 nm )fluorescence in tolu
chunks.summary: Researchers designed two D–π–A carbazole–sulfone fluorophores (CzS1, CzS2) with π-conjugation breaking, yielding high-quantum-yield intramolecular charge-transfer blue‑violet emission. Nondoped OLEDs achieved CIEy <0.06, peak current/power efficiencies up to 1.89 cd A−1 and 1.58 lm W−1. Figure shows molecular structures, emission spectra/CIE coordinates and device performance confirming record results for blue-violet OLEDs.

e local π\\piπ conjugation, Liu et al. recently developed a series of efficient deep-blue emitters which show electroluminescence CIE coordinates around (0.15, 0.10).10 Whereas room for further blue-shifting the emission still remains because the strong electron-donating NNN phenylnaphthalen-1-aminegroup (with relatively low oxidation potentials)10 and long π\\piπ bridges between the D and A units (3 to 4 benzene rings) were used in these emitters. Once replaced by other less electron-rich donors and shorter π\\piπ bridges, respectively, to limit the ICT trend and the molecular conjugation, the light emission can be further adjusted to shorter wavelength. Moss et al. systematically studied the photophysics of a series of electron-accepting dibenzothiophene S,S-dioxide (DBTO)-based fluorophores whic are modified with different kinds of D units.1 Among them, the carbazole/DBTO-connected fluorophores exhibit blue to violet (450 to 408 nm4 0 8 ~ \\mathrm { n m }408 nm )fluorescence in toluene solution. Their fluorescent quantum yields are yet either moderate (0.58) or even low (0.25). It is also noticeable that substantial conjugation exists across the DBTO unit, still leaving the chance for further blue-shifting the emission. Thereby, the key point for designing high-efficiency blue-violet to violet electroluminescence materials is to suitably control the π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ conjugation enlargement and the ICT trend inside the molecules.

![](https://storage.treer.ai/images/7bdbc5d01b43ddd08cac674f0c63e55d3b3bc72266094c1bd20a9caf92b17627.jpg)  
Scheme 1. Synthesis of Czs1\\mathbf { C } \\mathbf { z } \\mathbf { s } \\mathbf { 1 }Czs1 and CzS2

Herein, we utilized a carbazole/sulfone hybrid design strategy to obtain two novel efficient blue-violet fluorophores, di(4-(4-(carbazol-9-yl)phenyl)phenyl)sulfone (CzS1)\\mathbf { ( C z S 1 ) }(CzS1) and di(4- (9-phenylcarbazol-3-yl)phenyl)sulfone (CzS2)\\mathbf { ( C z S 2 ) }(CzS2) (Scheme 1). The widely used hole-transporting moiety, carbazole, was selected as the electron-donor (D) for its relatively mild electron-donating ability as compared to other arylamines.10c These D--A type molecules could thus have relatively weak ICT trends, which is beneficial for generating short-wavelength emissions. Besides, the sulfone group was chosen as the electron-acceptor (A) for its excellent electron injection/ as linked to two freely rotatable benzene rings in this work, can also serve as a π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ conjugation breaker because of its tetrahedral electronic conformation which could effectively confine the π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ . conjugation of the molecules. Finally, these compounds were designed to be bulky to enhance their morphological and thermal stability by using a symmetrical D. π⋅\\pi \\cdotπ⋅ A π\\piπ D structure. Bipolar charge-transporting characteristics of CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 were demonstrated with single-carrier type devices. Nondoped OLEDs based on the two novel fluorophores show blue-violet light emissions with CIEx,y\\mathrm { C I E } \_ { \\mathrm { x , y } }CIEx,y​ of (0.157, 0.055) and (0.157, 0.044), respectively. The CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 -based device exhibited excellent EL performance with high external quantum efficiency (EQE) of 4.2%4 . 2 \\%4.2% ,current efficiency (CE) of 1.89 cd A−1\\mathbf { A } ^ { - 1 }A−1 ,and power efficiency (PE) of 1.58lmW−11 . 5 8 \\mathrm { l m } \\mathrm { W } ^ { - 1 }1.58lmW−1 Performances of the devices are among the best of OLEDs with CIEy\\mathrm { C I E } \_ { y }CIEy​ below 0.06. In particular, to the best of our knowledge, the CE and PE obtained here have reached the highest values of reported blue-violet/violet OLEDs with CIEy\\mathrm { C I E } \_ { y }CIEy​ below 0.06.

# EXPERIMENTAL SECTION

General Procedures. 1H^ 1 \\mathrm { H }1H and 13C^ { 1 3 } \\mathrm { C }13C NMR spectra were measured with a Varian Gemini-400 Varian spectrometer. Mass spectra were recorded on a Finnigan 4021C GC-MS spectrometer. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was performed using a Perkin-Elmer Pyris DSC 6 instrument operated at a heating rate of 10 ∘C min−11 0 \\ ^ { \\circ } \\mathrm { C } \\ \\mathrm { m i n ^ { - 1 } }10 ∘C min−1 in a nitrogen atmosphere. The glass transition temperature (Tg)( T \_ { \\mathrm { g } } )(Tg​) was determined from the second heating scan. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was undertaken using a TA SDT Q600 instrument. The thermal stability of the samples under a nitrogen atmosphere was determined by measuring their weight losses while heating at a rate of 20∘C min−12 0 \\mathrm { ^ { \\circ } C \\ m i n ^ { - 1 } }20∘C min−1 .The absorption and emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi U-3010 UV-vis spectrophotometer and a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer, respectively. The film photoluminescence quantum yield was measured by the integrating sphere method, and the emission decay profile was measured with an Edinburgh F900
chunks.summary: Carbazole–sulfone D–A fluorophores CzS1 and CzS2 (Scheme 1: synthesis) were designed to restrict π‑conjugation and ICT, yielding blue‑violet nondoped OLEDs. Devices emit at CIE (0.157,0.055) and (0.157,0.044); CzS1 achieves EQE 4.2%, CE 1.89 cd·A−1 and PE 1.58 lm·W−1—top metrics for CIEy<0.06. Thermal, photophysical, and device characterizations are reported, including quantum yields and stability.

Quantum Calculation. Theoretical calculation of the compounds was carried out using the Gaussian-03 program. Density functional theory (DFT) B3LPY/6-31G(d) was used to determine and optimize the structures. Optimized structures were used for the calculation. No negative mode was found, indicating that the systems indeed correspond to a local energy minimum.

OLED Fabrication and Measurement. ITO coated glass with a sheet resistance of 30 Ω3 0 ~ \\Omega30 Ω square−1 was used as the substrate. Before device fabrication, the ITO glass substrates were cleaned with isopropyl alcohol and deionized water, dried in an oven at 120 ∘C,1 2 0 \\ ^ { \\circ } \\mathrm { C } ,120 ∘C, treated with UV-ozone, and finally transferred to a vacuum deposition system with a base pressure better than 1×10−61 \\times 1 0 ^ { - 6 }1×10−6 Torr for organic and metal deposition. The devices were fabricated by evaporating organic layers with an evaporation rate of 1−2 A ^s−11 - 2 \\hat { \\mathrm { ~ A ~ } } s ^ { - 1 }1−2 A ^s−1 The cathode was completed through thermal deposition of LiF at a deposition rate of 0.1 A˚ˉ s−10 . 1 \\ \\bar { \\mathrm { \\AA } } \\ s ^ { - 1 }0.1 A˚ˉ s−1 , and then capped with Al metal through thermal evaporation at a rate of 10 A˚s −11 0 \\textrm { \\AA s } ^ { - 1 }10 A˚s −1 The overlap between ITO and Al electrodes was 3.3×3.3 mm23 . 3 \\times 3 . 3 ~ \\mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }3.3×3.3 mm2 as the active emissive area of devices. EL luminescence, spectra, and CIE color coordinates were measured with a Spectrascan PR650 photometer, and the current—voltage characteristics were measured with a computer-controlled Keithley 2400 SourceMeter under ambient atmosphere.

Adachi and co-workers have recently made a milestone advance in the organic electroluminescence research field by introducing purely organic molecules that can give efficient thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) through upconversion of triplet to singlet states, and therefore lead to potentially 100%100 \\%100% internal singlet yields.10h,1 Among their reported TADF materials, compound 3, namely, di(4-(3,6-ditert-butylcarbazol-9-yl)phenyl)sulfone, shows pure-blue electroxel Q 9.9%9 . 9 \\%9.9% 1h o onsidering that the two compounds in this work have similar molecular structures with compound 3, we also explore their potential of TADF emission. Supporting Information, Figure S2 shows their room-temperature transient PL decay characteristics in an oxygen-free toluene solution. The samples were freshly nitrogen-purged to avoid any possible triplet quenching by oxygen. It is interesting to find that, in contrast to the case of compound 3 in the report of Adachi et al., both of our new compounds clearly exhibit first-order exponential decays which completely end within a short time range of 20 ns2 0 ~ \\mathrm { n s }20 ns Indeed, no delayed components were observed in both cases, indicating the absence of DATF emission from CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathbf { C } \\mathbf { z } \\mathbf { S } 2CzS2 We may mainly attribute this to the overwhelming emission transition rate over the nonemission transition rate of their photoinduced excited states. As mentioned above, CzS1 and CzS2 achieved near-unity fluorescent quantum yields even in the airequilibrated toluene solution, and therefore one can deduce that the intersystem crossing (ISC) process, one non-emission

As shown in Figure 9, all the four single-carrier devices show significant currents, indicating the bipolar charge-transporting abilities of both CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 and CzS2\\mathbf { C } \\mathbf { z } \\mathbf { S } 2CzS2 . Additionally, it is also found that the hole and electron currents of the CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 devices are both much higher, however, less balanced as compared to those of the CzS1 devices. These could explain why the light-emitting device based on CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 achieved relatively lower turn-on voltage and higher current density/luminescence while the CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 -based device achieved higher EL efficiencies. It is thus reflected that charge balance is an important factor for the device efficiencies.23

(a) Current density—voltage—luminance characteristics, (b) current efficiency-luminance—power efficiency plots, and (c) external quantum efficiency—luminance plots of the CzS1\\mathbf { \\boldsymbol { C } } \\mathbf { \\boldsymbol { z } } \\mathbf { \\boldsymbol { S } } 1CzS1 and the CzS2{ \\bf C } { \\bf z } { \\bf S } 2CzS2 based blue-violet light-emitting devices.

# CONCLUSIONS

In summary, two highly efficient blue-violet fluorophores, CzS1 and CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 , have been developed via a D π\\piπ A structure design strategy which incorporates carbazole as a mild electron-donor and sulfone as an electron-acceptor with a π\\piπ conjugationbreaking feature. Nondoped devices based on the two compounds exhibit blue-violet light emissions with CIE coordinates of (0.157, 0.055) for CzS1\\mathbf { C z S 1 }CzS1 and (0.157, 0.044) for CzS2\\mathrm { C z } \\mathrm { S } 2CzS2 at 100 cd m−21 0 0 \\ c \\mathrm { d } \\ \\mathrm { m } ^ { - 2 }100 cd m−2 respectively. CzS1\\mathrm { C z S 1 }CzS1 possesses much better balanced bipolar charge-transporting ability, and its electroluminescence device shows high performance with EQE, CE, and PE of 4.2%4 . 2 \\%4.2% ,1.89 cd A−1\\mathbf { A } ^ { - 1 }A−1 ,and 1.58 lm W−1.1 . 5 8 \\ \\mathrm { l m \\ W ^ { - 1 } } .1.58 lm W−1. respectively, which are among the best of blue-violet/violet OLEDs up until now. We here successfully provide an efficient design strategy for high-efficiency short-wavelength fluorophores.

Mater., J. Mater. Chem., Chem. Mater., and others.
